74286: Name Dropping.author: Kryptnyt
74286: Name Dropping.text_parsed:
If my opponent says "Counter", could I return Counterspell to my hand? (a cheaper spell counter)
In the same vein, if he says "Die" can I return Soldier of Fortune, Ladies' Knight, and Ironclaw Buzzardiers to my hand all at the same time?
One cringes at the possibilities for just saying "I enter my attack step," since "I" would return over 7400 different cards by itself.
So I'm going to guess, here, that the intended ruling would be a full, coherent word in the title of the card. Such as saying Well and returning Blinkmoth well and not wellwisher.

@SentByHim; no, it works while in play, there's no question to that. It's no Bridge From Below type card.

In the same vein, if he says "Die" can I return [autocard]Soldier of Fortune[/autocard], [autocard]Ladies' Knight[/autocard], and [autocard]Ironclaw Buzzardiers[/autocard] to my hand all at the same time?
One cringes at the possibilities for just saying "I enter my attack step," since "I" would return over 7400 different cards by itself.
So I'm going to guess, here, that the intended ruling would be a full, coherent word in the title of the card. Such as saying Well and returning [autocard]Blinkmoth well[/autocard] and not [autocard]wellwisher[/autocard].

@SentByHim; no, it works while in play, there's no question to that. It's no [autocard]Bridge From Below[/autocard] type card.

74290: Zombie Fanboy.author: mikato1
74290: Zombie Fanboy.text_parsed: pick on someone that uses a bunch of cards from one artist.
74290: Zombie Fanboy.text_posted: pick on someone that uses a bunch of cards from one artist.

74290: Zombie Fanboy.author: DoctorKenneth
74290: Zombie Fanboy.text_parsed:
So lets say you've got a playset of these kicking around, and you want to make some use out of them. You want to make a deck? Sure, lets make a deck. Come on.

Okay, so to make the most use out of your Fanboy, you'll want him triggering off of copies of himself. So the obvious choice of artist here is Matt Cavotta. "Is this going to be a Matt Cavotta theme deck?" I hear you ask. Why yes. Yes it is.

So to capitalize on our Cavotta investment, we'll want Drawn Together for a nice team boost. And since we're making creatures huge anyway, why not give them trample? Graphic Violence is our budget overrun. "But Doctor!" you now whine "We're now in three colours! And not even nice, Shard colours!" Fear not, Gatherites. I've got you covered. Rather, Matt does.

Cavotta was kind enough to illustrate a version of Yavimaya Elder, which will not only help us accelerate, but also trigger the fanboy. And with all this creature pump going around, a big fatty like Copperhoof Vorrac isn't unwelcome. Speaking of fat, Matt also gives us the combo-liscious Protean Hulk - though we don't really have much of a toolbox to fetch with him in this deck. Oh, and lets not forget Great Sable Stag for hosing down control. Tattermunge Maniac dropped early won't have much of a drawback by the time Drawn Together comes around, and even then, your Maniac is expendable with a Fanboy around.

A few fliers, of course, would be nice. When you're running a casual deck, you never know what you might face- good air support is always wanted. Skyhunter Patrol is good for the mid-range. Sadly, our flier range is limited here, but maybe you'll be smashing enough face so that won't matter.

Luckily, however, being in black gives us access to a host of removal. Go nuts. You don't need me to tell you what removal is awesome. Though don't forget that you have access to black AND white, and there is nothing sexier than the words "Destroy target permanent". You could even add a "and every permenent with the same name" for gravy. Note also that Erase (Not the Urza's Legacy One) and Remodel are good sideboard material.

Have fun, and be sure to thank Mr. Cavotta.

74300: Farewell to Arms.author: Ruopolo
74300: Farewell to Arms.text_parsed: After your left or right hand is chosen as a target you can always cut it off, so the target becomes illegal and the enchantment gets countered and goes to the graveyard. (You can do physical actions as a response to spells and abilities).
74300: Farewell to Arms.text_posted: After your left or right hand is chosen as a target you can always cut it off, so the target becomes illegal and the enchantment gets countered and goes to the graveyard. (You can do physical actions as a response to spells and abilities).

74303: Creature Guy.author: boneclub
74303: Creature Guy.text_parsed:
Because nobody seems to have pointed it out, if you put the flavourtexts in this order:
1. Creature Guy
2. Save Life
3. Deal Damage
4. Spell Counter
5. Kill Destroy

You get a nice little rhyme:
"There once was a player named Quinn, who consistently managed to win. Until he got singed, playing Unhinged, getting Gotcha'd again and again."
74303: Creature Guy.text_posted:
Because nobody seems to have pointed it out, if you put the flavourtexts in this order:
1. [autocard]Creature Guy[/autocard]
2. [autocard]Save Life[/autocard]
3. [autocard]Deal Damage[/autocard]
4. [autocard]Spell Counter[/autocard]
5. [autocard]Kill Destroy[/autocard]

You get a nice little rhyme:
"There once was a player named Quinn, who consistently managed to win. Until he got singed, playing [i]Unhinged[/i], getting Gotcha'd again and again."

74306: Cheatyface.author: KokoshoForPresident
74306: Cheatyface.text_parsed:
I was with my playgroup one night, and we have someone that's unofficially considered in charge because he knows more about magic than the rest of us. So, I was playing against him when one of my friends came over with a complaint that his opponent was cheating. My opponent went off on this rant about how cheating was totally wrong and he hated it and if you can't play the game right, you shouldn't play at all, etc., etc.
I had this guy in my pocket at the the time. You can probably guess what I did XD. Slipped him onto the table and casually said, "You ready to finish the game?"
I will treasure the look on his face forever.

74307: Head to Head.author: Ferlord
74307: Head to Head.text_parsed:
I love these little mini-games added to Magic in the Un-sets. It's a shame the effect of this card is kind of small. I mean, if it were a pseudo-Holy Day, that'd be nice. Or even a one-sided Holy Day (Prevent all damage dealt by your opponents this turn). That'd be really good! I guess we can't have our cake and eat it too, though.

Regardless, if you did play this in a casual environment, it's one of those cards that people won't be sour to see (unlike a Mox Lotus or a Johnny, Combo Player).

74312: Enter the Dungeon.author: Haliax
74312: Enter the Dungeon.text_parsed:
My thoughts on this card:
If you play a Double Deal or two, before initiating the subgame, the double tutor effect is even easier to claim (a subgame is still a game (and we're talking about playing Un-Magic, on top of it)).

You could reveal one to four Infernal Spawn of Infernal Spawn of Evils while using the dual tutor effect to take further advantage of this card.

74312: Enter the Dungeon.author: Mooby
74312: Enter the Dungeon.text_parsed:
This is actually a better designed card than Shahrazad. Starting at 5 life makes the subgame different from the regular game (and faster), and the tutor effect ends the main game faster. Toss this in a RB deck, do the 5 damage in 1-2 turns, and tutor up your winning 2 card combo.

Subgames could actually be done right if Shahrazad hadn't started them off so wrong. Looks like "restart the game" is its spiritual successor, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.

74315: Supersize.author: rulesinquisitor
74315: Supersize.text_parsed:
If you think about it +3.5/+3.5 is essentially the same as +4/+4. I mean, unless you are dealing with creatures that have non-integer stats to begin with.

My 2/2 bear attacks into your 5/5 creature. I give the bear Titanic Growth, making it a 6/6, killing your 5/5 and living to tell the tale. Alternatively, I give the bear Supersize, making it a 5.5/5.5, still coming out on top.

I'm not saying anything about the quality or power level of the card, objectively. I'm just saying that in a lot of cases, there's essentially no difference between this and M12's Titanic Growth. A 2/2 will kill a 5/5 whether it (the 2/2) has been pumped to 6/6 or 5.5/5.5.

The difference is only significant if you're staring down a 6/6 with your 2/2, in which case Supersize isn't going to be powerful enough to let the creatures trade in combat.

So yeah, Titanic Growth is pretty much strictly better, but whatever. It's an Uncard.

74317: Ambiguity.author: fourk
74317: Ambiguity.text_parsed:
I'm fairly certain that the examples provided by user @Bandswithother are incorrect, as they do not take mechanics of the stack into account.

Revised example:
P1: "I cast Ambiguity, you may go."
P2: "I cast disenchant on your end step."
P1: "In response, Counterspell."
P1: "Note that, by placing Counterspell on the stack, I have triggered the ability of ability of Ambiguity. Does this ability resolve?"
now, there are four ways that this can play out from here.

Way 1:
P2: "In response to Ambiguity's triggered ability, I play another Disenchant."
order of resolution: 2nd Disenchant, then Ambiguity's triggered ability, then Counterspell (removing first Disenchant from the stack)

Way 2/3/4:
P2: "Yes, I will let it resolve."
Way 2: P1:"I choose to counter the next spell played this turn." OR
Way 3: P1:"I choose to place a counter on a permanent that is already in play and already has at least one counter on it. The counter is of a type that the permanent already has one or more counters of that type on it.(if a permanent has -1/-1 counters and +1/+1 counters, for example, you may choose to put one counter of either type on the permanent)" OR
Way 4: P1: "I choose not to use this ability, on the basis of the word 'may' in the card text."

The one issue that I'm unsure of, is how to interpret "that has already been played, but not countered" part of determining a valid permanent to put an additional counter on. I'd imagine that this means that if I were to discard a Spike Drone then play Reanimate to bring that Spike Drone into play, it would not be a valid recipient of a counter from Ambiguity. However, if I had played the Spike Drone, then used its ability (thus killing it as a state based effect), then Reanimated it, it would be a valid recipient. If I had attempted to play Spike Drone, had it counterspelled, then used Reanimate to put it in play, it would also not be a valid recipient.

Also, note that Ambiguity only triggers (for the counterspell trigger) when someone plays a counter spell targetting a spell that was PLAYED, not copied. Playing a counter on a Storm copy, Fork copy, Conspire copy, etc, would not trigger it.

None of the "simplified/deciphered" versions of the text in this thread come close to actually fully encompassing the card as worded in the Oracle text. 'Ambiguity' doesn't really describe this card so much as 'overly complicated'.

74317: Ambiguity.author: Bandswithother
74317: Ambiguity.text_parsed:
Another way of putting it to the confused: whenever you or an opponent plays a counter spell, they get an optional free counter spell for the next spell played. OR if you play a card that comes into play with counters on it (like a planeswalker) you may put an additional counter on another planeswalker or a Zendikar quest (much like proliferate, but for only one permanent).

Both of these effects work interchangeably too. You can cast a planeswalker and counter the next spell played or you can counter a spell and put another counter on your walker.

Errata: Fourk is correct, I changed my first example to reflect it. However my other examples are perfectly fine.

Examples:

P1: "I cast Ambiguity, you may go."
P2:"I disenchant it on your end step."
"Counterspell."
"Fine. Untap. Draw. Oh another Disenchant, now I'll blow up your Ambiguity."
"I counter it."
"But you're tapped out."
"Read Ambiguity again."


P1: "I cast Sorin Markov and drop your life to 10"
P2: "I Bolt him."
"I counter it."
"But you don't have any cards in your hand!"
"Read Ambiguity again."

P2: "I cast Unmake."
P1: "I counter it, and put another -1/-1 counter on your bloodied ghost."
"what?"
"Read Ambiguity again."

P2: "I cast Bloodied Ghost, and put another Loyalty counter on my Elspeth"
P1: "Now you're learning!"

74317: Ambiguity.author: Continue
74317: Ambiguity.text_parsed:
There are four possible things that may be done with this card. They are as follows:

1) A player counters a spell.
a) That player may counter the next spell that is cast.
b) That player may put a counter on a permanent, limited to a type of counter already on that permanent. (I assume this card follows proliferate rules, but this is Unhinged, so perhaps not.)

2) A player casts a spell that, when it resolves, enters the battlefield with counters on it — for example, a planeswalker or an Arcbound creature.
a) That player may counter the next spell that is cast.
b) That player may put a counter on a permanent, limited to a type of counter already on that permanent.

Hope this helps anyone who was confused about this card's functionality. Do note that you may also choose to do neither, but you would need to wait until both a spell is cast and a permanent enters the battlefield with counters to determine that you will do nothing.

I think I've nailed the wording on this using current syntax.

Whenever a player casts a spell that counters a spell on the stack or whenever a player casts a permanent spell that would cause the permanent which resolves from that spell to enter the battlefield with one or more counters on it, that player may counter the next spell played this game or choose a nonland permanent with one or more counters on it that entered the battlefield as a resolved permanent spell or a land with one or more counters on it that entered the battlefield as the result of a land play and give it another counter of a kind already there.

So.
Combo with Opalescence and Torpor Orb and you can ignore the entire first paragraph on this card.

74318: Form of the Squirrel.author: mutantman
74318: Form of the Squirrel.text_parsed:
You can't use Opalescence + Torpor Orb to stop the token from being created because the token is actually created as part of a replacement effect that modifies the way it enters the battlefield (a la Clone, Coldsteel Heart, etc.), not as a triggered ability. Note the "As this comes into play" wording as opposed to "When this comes into play".

This replacement effect creates a delayed triggered ability that will go off when the token leaves play, much like the abilities of Phantasmal Mount or Dance of the Dead.

The question is, if you Donate the enchantment away before it triggers, who will lose the game?

The answer can be found in 603.7f (emphasis added):

603.7f If a static ability generates a replacement effect which causes a delayed triggered ability to
be created, the source of that delayed triggered ability is the object with that static ability. The
controller of that delayed triggered ability is the same as the controller of that object at the time
the replacement effect was applied.

If the enchantment entered the battlefield under your control, you will lose the game when the squirrel token leaves play no matter who controls the enchantment at that time.

A previous post mentioned Phasing. This is a combo. Phasing out does not trigger leaves-play abilities (702.24d), and a phased-out token ceases to exist as a state-based action (702.24k). So if you manage to phase out the token (for example, with Teferi's Veil), you will not lose the game when it leaves, and the token will never come back. You cannot, however, phase out the enchantment to prevent it from triggering (a delayed triggered ability can still trigger even if the original source is no longer around).

74318: Form of the Squirrel.author: MechaKraken
74318: Form of the Squirrel.text_parsed:
So apparently, according to the ruling on this card, it can leave play, but as long as the squirrel token that is produced by it is still on the field, you won't lose. So... does that mean that when the enchantment leaves play, the token becomes just a plain ol' 1/1 squirrel token with no abilities? Since all of the errata is on the card, and not the token. For that matter, what would happen if an opponent flickered this enchantment, thus producing TWO squirrel tokens under your control? The card says that you cannot be chosen for a spell or ability by the opponent, but it says nothing about the card itself having that same protection. And what would happen if one of your tokens die, but the other is still on the field?

On a side-note, this card seems to have been made for stylish wins. Which is already pure awesome. Some ideas I had were playing Jhoira of the Ghitu, then using her ability to suspend Worldfire, then suspend this card. When the suspend counters are used up, everyone loses all permanents, hands, and their life is 1, while you have an enchantment coming in immediately after giving you a 1/1 creature to attack with =). Another idea might be attacking with Master of Cruelties, and then swinging in with your squirrel token next turn for game.

To truly appreciate this card, zany combos need to be played with it. And when those combos do succeed, even if only just once, it will provide amusement for many, many days to come when telling the story of that match =)

74321: Topsy Turvy.author: mutantman
74321: Topsy Turvy.text_parsed: Ultra-broken combo with Vedalken Mastermind. Two cards, infinite turns. See, if you bounce the Topsy Turvy during your opponent's end step, then suddenly the beginning of their turn becomes the end of their turn once again, and it rolls back to your turn, during which you can attack, replay the Topsy Turvy in your postcombat main phase, roll back to your untap step, and repeat the process until they're dead. Turn 3 lockdown.

74321: Topsy Turvy.author: A3Kitsune
74321: Topsy Turvy.text_parsed: Great with cards that have a 'during your upkeep' or 'beginning of your upkeep' positive effect - you get the effect the turn you play it. Run this with any alternate win condition card that triggers at the beginning of your upkeep. Also goes well with expensive counterspells - you untap at the end of your turn, so all your mana is available on your opponent's turn.

74323: Mox Lotus.author: beefrocks
74323: Mox Lotus.text_parsed:
Quite obviously the best card ever. It works great with Gleemax, Sliver Queen, Blaze, Clockwork Dragon, and so many others I couldn't dream of mentioning them all by name. Not to mention that it makes those really annoying cards like Scald obsolete.

Of course, it has one huge downside. If that card is tapped and it gets destroyed, you better have some backup plan or you'll be losing infinity life due to mana burn.... Of course, I like to make a distinction between "infinite" (infinity - infinity = 0) and "virtually infinite" (infinity - virtually infinity = infinity) so that I can spend all that mana on something just in case. Sometimes your friends will let you play like that, but I'm not sure how the official rules would look on that.

One card combo especially worth mentioning: Put an Essence Sliver, a Sliver Queen, and a Magma Sliver out on the field, and tap Mox Lotus. Use the mana to get a bunch of 1/1 colorless Sliver creature tokens, tap some of those to empower the others, and then attack. Any attack that doesn't get neutralized somehow will deal damage to something, and the Essence Sliver's special ability will kick in, giving you a crap-load of life.

(Sorry for the lack of a link to look up the Magma Sliver. It kept glitching up for some reason.)

74323: Mox Lotus.author: Russian.Thunder
74323: Mox Lotus.text_parsed:
If we're going to get technical here, this card isn't all that great. Using the ability will put an ability on the stack that adds a colorless mana to your pool an infinite number of times. So, the ability would remain on the stack indefinitely, making it impossible to play spells that aren't instants (or don't have flash) and impossible to end the current phase...

WAIT! Nevermind. It's a mana ability. Doesn't use the stack. paradox avoided.

5/5

74323: Mox Lotus.author: CunsoTheRandom
74323: Mox Lotus.text_parsed:
I like the card, but I really wish they would have made it like every other Mox. I understand that the joke is that if you can afford to cast it you should have already won the game by now anyway, but they could have been a bit creative with that idea with additional costs.

Perhaps they could have tried something like the following (just an example):
As an additional cost to play Mox Lotus, choose one - Pay 49 life; or remove 200 cards from your library; or remove twenty creature cards from your graveyard; or sacrifice twenty creatures.

Something cute like that to reference iconic alternate win-condition cards where if you were playing one of those cards you would have won already anyway. If you didn't catch the cards referenced, they were in order: Test of Endurance, Battle of Wits, Mortal Combat, and Epic Struggle.

Another possible option is to push the "you should have won already" theme:
You can only play Mox Lotus if your opponent has exactly 1 life, or if you have played ten or more spells this turn. or if you have drawn 8 or more cards this turn, or the total power of creatures you control is twenty or higher.

@ azure_drake222222: Really? That doesn't seem possible. What happens when it's destroyed without infinite mana in your pool? The joke is that you should be able to win already with fifteen mana, so infinite mana is just about the same as fifteen. That's probably true in most sixty-card constructed decks, but maybe not Commander, so it could be a reasonable card to use in a fun deck if your group doesn't mind Un-Cards.

74324: Rocket-Powered Turbo Slug.author: ZakFrost
74324: Rocket-Powered Turbo Slug.text_parsed:
In response to all of the super-blanks, I would like to point out that some of those already exist:
Super-flying: Unblockable.

Super-regeneration: Meet Reassembling Skeleton.

Super-Shroud(aka troll shroud, from Troll Ascetic): They're adding the keyword in magic 2012 as "Hexproof", but it's already been in cards (possibly the best is the troll, as he also has regeneration, making him almost unkillable), it's a shroud that only effects your opponents, so you can buff your creature all you want with Giant Growth, and the other guy(s) can't lightning bolt it. In normal Shroud no one can target it with a spell or ability, including it's owner.

Super-Trample: It doesn't actually have a name, yet, but it that thing where you can assign your combat damage to a creature to it's controller instead. Some people say that's not better, as it doesn't kill the creature, but it's almost like an unblockable, except you get to decide if you want to kill a creature or be unblocked, and the creature who has it does get hit, but most creatures who have it have plenty of toughness anyway. An old card that has this is Rhox.

74324: Rocket-Powered Turbo Slug.author: DarthParallax
74324: Rocket-Powered Turbo Slug.text_parsed:
Super Toilet: Flush target player's library into the graveyard.

Oh wait, they did that already. Jace, the Mind Sculptor.

It is worth noting that this is the ONLY card in the game that 60 copies of will actually win a game.

It is 'effectively' 0 cost, so you don't need lands if you can win Turn 1. Which you can.

It deals damage, which very few 0-cost cards do.

The damage is inequal- it does more damage to your opponent than to you, which is not true of Gut Shot, which is one of the best 0-cost damage spells there are.

You can have 7 of this in your opening hand. 7x3 = 21.

If you were playing EDH, I would suggest bringing 100 Rocket-Powered Turbo Slugs to the table, calling one of them your commander, and playing all 8 on your first turn to kill "That One Guy" that everyone in your group hates immediately with 24 General Damage. When he protests that your deck is the most *** thing he's ever seen (cuz it is), put it to a Vote. If he's really a "That Guy", then he'll deserve to lose and your group will say "yeah, that's totally how that works".

:D

74324: Rocket-Powered Turbo Slug.author: TheVizier
74324: Rocket-Powered Turbo Slug.text_parsed:
Super flying: Cannot be blocked by creatures with flying or reach.
Super vigilance: Attacking doesn't cause this creature to tap. This creature can block while tapped.
Super lifelink: Any damage this creature does causes you to gain that much life. Any damage this creature takes causes you to gain that much life.
Super shroud: This creature ignores all abilities (ex., if another creature has an ability that says "this creature can't be blocked except by two or more creatures", this creature may block it. Or if it blocks a creature with lifelink, the creature with lifelink's controller doesn't gain life.)
Super hexproof: If a spell or ability an opponent controls targets this creature, instead it targets another target of your choice.
Super deathtouch: Any damage this creatures deals counts as lethal damage. If a creature dealt damage by this creature would die, exile it instead.
Super intimidate: This creature can only be blocked by creatures that share the exact same color(s) with it. (ex., a white/green creature with super intimidate can only be blocked by another white/green creature.)
Super landwalk (a.k.a. colorwalk): This creature can't be blocked as long as defending player controls a permanent of the chosen color.
Super reach: This creature can block creatures that can't be blocked, besides creatures with super flying, super landwalk (if it is the color chosen), or super intimidate (if it isn't the same colors).
Super indestructible: This creature cannot be destroyed or exiled.

Great pun, and very interesting artwork. I can recognize seven out of these 16(?) creatures illustrated there right now, although most of them look familiar to me.
Yet i'm not sure the guy on the bottom right with the "help me" sign actually exists.

The animated series of the same name is also great, by the way :D

Edit (since 8/29/2009):
@ultratog1028: Dang you're right! Now i see the Cabal Trainee's artwork again it's so obvious. He seemed to wear a red-blue striped cloak and overall more comic-like so i supposed he'd be an unglued-only character. So this sign might even refer to the faceshredder he's about to get killed by on the original card. Or simply the Flametongue Kavu that looks down to him.

Great work on the list. I think i can complete your list now.

(Didn't even notice the Storm Spirit on the top left, and I had problems making out what goblin used that ballon again, i knew it was an old one but i forgot about the Portal artwork from Goblin Glider.)

The other dragon left from Firestorm Hellkite is Crosis, the Purger. I think i can see a Saprazzan Breaker between both.
The Goblin on the bottom left is likely Skirk Marauder. (Possibly also the one in the middle of Mons's Goblin Raiders, but i don't think so.)
The handsome man next to Shauku is Baron Sengir.
The one in the middle above them and below Megatog is Cabal Archon.

Maybe, just maybe the Baron Sengir x Shauku ship is a very subliminal reference to Princess Clara and the Delivery Guy (aka Satan) from the Episode Lost in Parking Space? :D

74331: Yet Another Aether Vortex.author: cybishop
74331: Yet Another Aether Vortex.text_parsed:
The Unhinged FAQ (http://www.wizards.com/magic/tcg/article.aspx?x=magic/faq/unhinged) says that this triggers "leaves play" effects, but not "comes into play" effects ("enters the battlefield", now). So I'd assume that a Ball Lightning would be sacrificed at the end of the turn you reveal it.

The FAQ also says that creature enchantments are revealed, considered to be in play, and sacrificed because they aren't enchanting anything before you have a chance to do anything with them. Likewise, I think the same would be true of planeswalkers. They are sacrificed as a state-based effect when they run out of loyalty counters, right? Loyalty counters are put on them when they enter the battlefield, but remember, cards on top of your library don't trigger "enters the battlefield" effects with this. So a planeswalker or creature enchantment would be revealed and immediately sacrificed. That's pretty powerful.

The FAQ also says that creature enchantments are revealed, considered to be in play, and sacrificed because they aren't enchanting anything before you have a chance to do anything with them. 74331: Yet Another Aether Vortex.author: KikiJikiTiki
74331: Yet Another Aether Vortex.text_parsed:
I agree in that I would like a card like this to exist in a fully functional set. I want to look for everything that would work well with it, but it seems like kind of waste when I know some of the people I play with won't even acknowledge cards with a silver border.

It works similarly to Renegade Doppelganger in that it doesn't trigger enters the battlefield triggers, but it can trigger leaves the battlefield triggers. This is much easier to trigger those leaves the battlefield triggers with.

Consider Wormfang Manta.
Firemaw Kavu
Thalakos Seer
Nevermaker
Slithermuse
Spitebellows

Utilizing Azami, Lady of Scrolls with this in a wizard deck (I think it should be blue anyway) would allow you to draw a ridiculous amount of cards, especially when combined with Information Dealer and Descendant of Soramaro.

(edit) Looking at the official Unhinged FAQ, I'm second-guessing its abilities. The FAQ says that the card triggers leaves the battlefield triggers in a way similar to phasing, but phasing no longer causes leaves the battlefield triggers to trigger (it did at the time the set came out). I really wish they would create official rulings for these cards. :(

If two or more objects would receive a timestamp simultaneously, such as by entering a zone simultaneously or becoming attached simultaneously, the active player determines their timestamp order at that time.

TLDR Whoever's turn it is gets to pick which effect is applied first

74331: Yet Another Aether Vortex.author: Tribor
74331: Yet Another Aether Vortex.text_parsed:
My brother has made a deck around this card, and it's so well built that everyone in our playgroup allows it. Some of it's champions are Eater of Days and Wormfang Manta, since their ETB effects don't activate. Vanishing cards such as Aven Rif***cher and Keldon Marauders are prominent for obvious reasons. He also uses scry to rearrange what will be on his side of the battlefield.

It's not absolutely broken however, since every other player also has the potential to suddenly have their strongest creature on the battlefield, an extra land to tap or an artifact to activate. It murders any creatures that would usually clone something but has 0/0 stats though.

74333: Pygmy Giant.author: Salient
74333: Pygmy Giant.text_parsed:
The greatest amount of damage you can do with this card is 1,000,000 if you're going by printed numbers only (edited to address the "24 million" Kobold). This gives the seventh edition Llanowar Elves a reason to exist, and lets you kill a 1000000/1000000 creature with Dracula, literally quoting from Bram Stoker. How cool is that?

If Pygmy Giant flung noncreature cards instead of creature cards, you'd top out at 700,000 with Relentless Assault.

The next time you think to yourself "I must be the geekiest person alive," remember that someone sat down, wrote an algorithm to automatically search the Gatherer database using regular expressions to find instances of numbers, and organized the results by magnitude -- just to leave a silly comment on an Unhinged card in Gatherer...

Edit: ....but I forgot to search for number words like "million" :(
74333: Pygmy Giant.text_posted:

74339: Spell Counter.author: boneclub
74339: Spell Counter.text_parsed:
Because nobody seems to have pointed it out, if you put the flavourtexts in this order:
1. Creature Guy
2. Save Life
3. Deal Damage
4. Spell Counter
5. Kill Destroy

You get a nice little rhyme:
"There once was a player named Quinn, who consistently managed to win. Until he got singed, playing Unhinged, getting Gotcha'd again and again."

74339: Spell Counter.author: DukeofDellot
74339: Spell Counter.text_parsed:
So I put together a cube based on this set. It started out with every card in the set, and I'm slowly figuring out which cards from the set are entertaining enough to play, and powerful enough to get selected when drafting.

This card is ridiculous. In a duel, you might get to cast it three times, and since it's a hard counter, it's a frightening thing that will make players careful about what they say. But since the spirit of the cube demands multiplayer...

Four way planechase, one of your buddies has this card in their graveyard, has the mana untapped, and there's a spell you really want him to counter (Staying Power) on the stack. Do you trigger the gotcha hoping that your buddy will counter the spell in question? What if he decides that the spell you want him to counter isn't worth it, but activates the Gotcha anyways?

It creates so many interesting situations that this guy has become of the "first picks" of the cube.
74339: Spell Counter.text_posted:

Do you trigger the gotcha hoping that your buddy will counter the spell in question?  What if he decides that the spell you want him to counter isn't worth it, but activates the Gotcha anyways?

74342: Time Machine.author: TheWrathofShane
74342: Time Machine.text_parsed:
What an awesome card!! I would prolong a game if I had a win, tutor x4 time machines and x4 birds of paradise. Then next game I would start with x4 birds with 7 cards in hand. Right before I win that game I would tap the machines and send off the birds, or when the machine//birds are about to die!

I dont think I would ever loose a game verse that opponent after that. Unless he did coupon + cheatyface combo.

Then again he could just scoop on turn 1 next game, and I cannot respond to his concede by activating time machine. That right there would hose my combo, and the card altogether.

So really you need to do 1 time machine + a reasonable card so your opponent does not scoop. Win is a win but its no fun when your opponent does not play.

74347: Meddling Kids.author: infernox10
74347: Meddling Kids.text_parsed:
Seriously, if this card wasn't in "Un",
This would see tournament play.
This is hard lockdown, between "target" to get rid of removal,
"damage" to get rid of burn, evergreens like lifelink/deathtouch or infect, etc. as long as there's reminder text,
Even "can't" would remove a lot of things that could be a threat,
Though if you plan to play more than one of these, make the last one "can't".

74348: Fascist Art Director.author: immelmann
74348: Fascist Art Director.text_parsed:
A little bit of story behind the card:

Art Director Jeremy Cranford received a TON of fan outrage when he decided to stop commissioning Rebecca Guay to do artwork, because apparently her art didnt fit into his vision for MTG. A lot of the outburst was over her being "fired". WOTC, in additional to clarifying their stance (she wasnt fired, they just stopped commissioning her), they paid her to do an unhinged card:

Persecute Artist
74348: Fascist Art Director.text_posted:
A little bit of story behind the card:

Art Director Jeremy Cranford received a [b]TON[/b] of fan outrage when he decided to stop commissioning Rebecca Guay to do artwork, because apparently her art didnt fit into his vision for MTG. A lot of the outburst was over her being "fired". WOTC, in additional to clarifying their stance (she wasnt [i]fired[/i], they just stopped commissioning her), they paid her to do an unhinged card:

74354: Collector Protector.author: CunsoTheRandom
74354: Collector Protector.text_parsed:
Here's a fun combo borrowed from Blacker Lotus:

First, Donate a Collector Protector.

Have in play the following cards:
Mycosynth Lattice, which turns all permanents into artifacts.
March of the Machines, which turns all of the non-creature artifacts into creatures.
Mindslaver
Blacker Lotus

Use the Mindslaver to control the opponent's next turn, then during their turn use Mirrorweave targeting Blacker Lotus to turn all permanents into Blacker Lotus. Tear up all of your opponent's permanents except for Collector Protector for 4 white mana each, and use all of that mana to activate the opponent's Collector Protector as many times as possible, making them give you the most valuable cards in their collection.

Congratulations, you now have no friends and possibly a lawsuit!
74354: Collector Protector.text_posted:
Here's a fun combo borrowed from [autocard]Blacker Lotus[/autocard]:

First, [autocard]Donate[/autocard] a [autocard]Collector Protector[/autocard].

Have in play the following cards:
[autocard]Mycosynth Lattice[/autocard], which turns all permanents into artifacts.
[autocard]March of the Machines[/autocard], which turns all of the non-creature artifacts into creatures.
[autocard]Mindslaver[/autocard]
[autocard]Blacker Lotus[/autocard]

Use the [autocard]Mindslaver[/autocard] to control the opponent's next turn, then during their turn use [autocard]Mirrorweave[/autocard] targeting [autocard]Blacker Lotus[/autocard] to turn all permanents into [autocard]Blacker Lotus[/autocard]. Tear up all of your opponent's permanents except for [autocard]Collector Protector[/autocard] for 4 white mana each, and use all of that mana to activate the opponent's [autocard]Collector Protector[/autocard] as many times as possible, making them give you the most valuable cards in their collection.

Congratulations, you now have no friends and possibly a [autocard multiverseid="1153"]lawsuit[/autocard]!

74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.author: will_dice
74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.text_parsed:
@artemoila
What is the converted mana cost of this?

One, two, three, three and four. Yes, three twice. And not, this is not a 13, it is a 1 and a 2 and so on.

Well, this except while on the stack, where it's only the CMC of the part you chose to cast, and if you're casting "Who", the CMC depends on the value of X (it would be 1+X).

So, if you're wanting to put it on a Isochron Scepter, it has a converted mana cost below two, so you can imprint it. It also has a CMC greater than 2, but the Scepter only asks if it has a CMC below 2, and it has.
On the other hand, if you're revealing it for Dark Confidant, you will lose 1 life and 2 life and 3 life and 3 life and 4 life, for a total of 13 life.
And finally, Spell Snare can only counter it if you're casting as a "Why" or a "Who" if X=1, nothing else.

Yes, split cards are a bit exotic, even outside of un-cards.

74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.author: Gelzo
74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.text_parsed:
"Okay, I'm casting When."

"I don't know man, I'm not going to play your deck for you. What are you even casting?"

"No, I'm not casting What. I chose When."

"Well, of course you chose when you cast it. Just tell me the spell you're casting."

"When."

"Now!"

"Yes, of course I'm casting it now. I'm targeting your creature spell."

"Okay, fine. Whatever. Wait, why?"

"You idiot, I can't target spells with Why."

"What?"

"Can't target your spell with that, either."

"Then, how exactly is your spell doing that?"

"How isn't on the card."

"Why?"

"That one is, though."

"Screw it! I concede. There's no way I can gain enough life to win at this point anyway."

"You know, Who might be able to help with that."

"Who?"

"Exactly."

"Nevermind. Let's try out our other decks."

"Neat. Can I use my Ambiguity deck?"

"What does that use?"

"It doesn't use What. It's just a blue deck."

"Uh, okay. Sure."

74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.author: fissionessence
74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #23 - 7/25/2011 - Who/What/When/Where/Why

Hm. This might actually be a reasonable card in a 5-color Commander deck. I'd seen this card before and thought it was a funny 'split card' progression, but I'd never actually considered playing with it. Each piece is an overcosted version of some simple effect, though not significantly overcosted. And each of those effects could potentially be pretty useful within a game of Commander. I don't know the general expected etiquette of Commander games when it comes to Un- cards, though. Of course, they're not black-bordered so they're not 'allowed' technically, and I've never seen someone playing with one, but I think if you just starting casting one, people would just laugh and continue enjoying the game. Even the 'target player' on the Who portion makes this potentially a political card as much as it is versatile.

On another note, split cards are supposed to be read as "X and Y". In the case of a five-card split, I guess the correct reading is "Who What When Where and Why." Also, for anyone interested in such things, while normally a cards' mana symbols and color references are according to the color-wheel-order (white, blue, black, red, green; with rules about what to do with enemy colors and green-white, etc.), split cards's color order were, of course, determined by the phrase that named them. For instance, in a blue-red pairing, blue comes first, but on Fire/Ice, red came first because of the term 'fire and ice'. And in the case of this card, we see a mish-mash of colors in different shapes and sizes just to make the concept work.

74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.author: Doghealer
74358: Who // What // When // Where // W.text_parsed:
If you're playing a five-color deck, and your opponents don't mind you using Un-cards that are only kind of Unhinged/Unglued (Y'know, cards that still function completely under the normal comprehensive rules), this is actually a really good control card.

Assuming you have access to one mana of any color, you can destroy ANY problematic noncreature, nonplanswalker for 4 or less. Plus you can stop any problematic creature as long as its still on the stack. Basically, the only thing it won't get rid of in planeswalkers.

You almost have a card that says "Destroy target permanent." An advanced search for cards with the text "destroy target permanent" returned 16 results.

Out of all 16 of those cards, 15 of them are A) A heck of a lot more expensive and/or B) Have some sort of targeting restriction. Only one (Vindicate) is cheaper.

I would definitely play this in any casual, 5-color, control-ish deck.

Because nobody seems to have pointed it out, if you put the flavourtexts in this order:
1. Creature Guy
2. Save Life

5. Kill Destroy

You get a nice little rhyme:
"There once was a player named Quinn, who consistently managed to win. Until he got singed, playing Unhinged, getting Gotcha'd again and again."

74360: Look at Me, I'm R&D.author: Aaron_Forsythe
74360: Look at Me, I'm R&D.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #35, 11/12/10

Many cards in the silver-bordered Unhinged set riff off of existing black-bordered Magic cards, but this one is a reference to a prior silver-bordered card from the Unglued set, Look at Me, I'm the DCI.

Whereas “the DCI” is a mysterious, shady front of an organization whose name used to be an abbreviation for something people no longer remember (and is now just a string of letters), “R&D” is a real, concrete body of actual humans, many of whom I have met. And R&D’s initials actually stand for something: Randy & Del.

Randy Buelher, former Director of Magic R&D, and his wife, Del Laugel, current Senior Magic Editor, are the first family of making Magic, so it makes sense that the department is named after them. The blue handwriting on this particular card is, in fact, Randy’s. (The red editorial markings on Frazzled Editor, also in Unhinged, are Del’s work.)

Randy contributed quite a bit to this particular card beyond the hours of playtesting that convinced him to make those hand-written changes. The Moat that was ruined when the sticker was applied came from his personal collection, and while he didn’t get to illustrate the card the way Mark Rosewater (under constant surveillance for allegedly being a member of the DCI at one point) did for Look at Me, I'm the DCI, he did get to hand-select the artist chosen to do the painting. As you can see from the scribblings at the bottom, he nominated famous the famous Scandinavian surrealist known only as “Sporkj” (that is not a semicolon, I swear, and it certainly isn’t part of some sort of set-wide secret message buried in the legal text), as Sporkj is the only talent on the planet capable of capturing Randy’s full countenance suitably.

Unfortunately, he missed his deadline and we had to use the sticker.

Here’s to more random Un-set cards!
